Issue.title: Issue
Issue.description: Represents an issue reported on the production line.

location.description: Location of the issue on the production line.

severity.description: Severity level of the issue (e.g., low, medium, high).

priority.description: Priority level of the issue as determined by AI.

status.description: Current status of the issue (e.g., reported, in progress, resolved).

reportedBy.description: Reference to User who reported the issue. (Relationship: User 1:N Issue)

assignedTo.description: Reference to User assigned to resolve the issue. (Relationship: User 1:N Issue)

reportedDate.description: The date and time the issue was reported.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the application.

role.description: Role of the user (e.g., operator, supervisor, admin).

FacilityKeyword.title: FacilityKeyword
FacilityKeyword.description: Represents a keyword relevant to a specific facility.

id.description: Unique identifier for the facility keyword.

ProductionLine.title: ProductionLine
ProductionLine.description: Represents a production line in the factory.

id.description: Unique identifier for the production line.

name.description: The name of the production line.

workstations.description: A list of workstation names on this line.

definition.description: Stores user profiles. User ID is used for authentication.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user.

definition.description: Stores all reported issues in a single collection for easy querying and analysis.

params.name: issueId
params.description: The unique identifier for the issue.

definition.description: Stores all production lines in a single collection.

params.name: lineId
params.description: The unique identifier for the production line.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure uses top-level collections for Users, Issues, and ProductionLines. This flat structure simplifies queries, as all data for a given type is in one place. Security rules will be used to control access. For example, while all issues are in one collection, rules will ensure that only authorized users (like admins or supervisors) can view all issues, while operators might only see issues they reported.
